prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal 1: eta Cha association
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal 1 is to measure dust mass in the selected sample of disks in eta Cha, and also detect gas in these young debris disk systems. We will use moderate spatial resolution, favouring sensitivity in our spectral setup. An advantage of the eta Cha targets is that all of them are close together on the sky (within 2 degrees), hence a common phase/gain calibrator can be used.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim for 10-sigma detections on all 10 sources presented in the science case (we are not repeating the ET Cha observations from Cycle 0). Four targets in eta Cha have 160 um detections above 40 mJy (not including ET Cha). In the beta Pic moving group, all 6 are above 30 mJy. For dust emission, assuming beta = 1 and T = 60K, the 160/1300 um ratio is 100, lower limit since we are assuming no extra cold component. That implies a total of 0.5 mJy for all the targets. Therefore, we aim for a continuum 1 sigma RMS of 0.05 mJy/beam, or 15 minutes on each source (13 sources). We ask for 3.2 hr total on source time, or 4 hr including overheads. With a band 6 resolution of 0.25 arcsec we will be able to resolve some of the disks. An advantage of the eta Cha targets is that all of them are close together on the sky (within 2 degrees), hence a common phase/gain calibrator can be used.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal 2: beta Pic moving group part I

An advantage of the eta Cha targets is that all of them are close together on the sky (within 2 degrees), hence a common phase/gain calibrator can be used.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The η Chamaeleontis association and the β Pictoris moving group of young low-luminosity nearby stars, represents an ideal laboratory to study planet formation at a critical age range: between 8 and 20 Myr. This stage is regarded as post protoplanetary/primordial disk, hence they are assumed to be young debris disks. We propose to conduct ALMA band 6 observations of 10 systems with clear excesses of emission at long wavelengths, evidencing the presence of circumstellar disks. Some of these systems may also contain disks with inner cavities (based on SED studies). The aims of this proposal concern mainly the determination of disk masses, sizes and detect primordial gas. Recent studies have shown evidence that some of these ’debris’ disks might still contain appreciable quantities of gas, challenging the idea that most disks lose all their gas at a rather early age (2-10 Myr).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
